0.00.text:
Translator: Morgane Quilfen
Reviewer: Theresa Ranft

15.20.text:
and just under four years ago,
at the age of 29,

19.54.text: I was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.

23.58.text:
I can't control my own slides
because my hands are shaking too much,

26.76.text: so someone's controlling them for me.

28.54.text:
It's you, that's where
I need to look. Thank you.

31.09.text:
I'm going to do this every time
I need to control it.

37.18.text:
I want to talk to you
about what Parkinson's has taught me

45.53.text: I was diagnosed just under four years ago

52.04.text: No one is at that age. No one is.

54.78.text: If you're a girl under a particular age,

56.69.text:
I think it's quite rare
for women to get it,

58.75.text:
and it's definitely rare
for 29-year-old women to get it.

63.31.text:
I'd had a strange feeling
in my right arm for a long time.

66.02.text:
Something that I couldn't pin down
to anything in particular.

70.37.text:
And it was eventually
that my dad said to me,

72.88.text: 'Go to the doctors, get it sorted.

74.77.text:
You need to get this sorted,
it's really important'.

79.37.text: And they took me for brain scans,

81.37.text:
and I thought, 'Ooh,
we're getting serious now.

83.69.text:
This is getting a bit --
it's kind of risky territory'.

88.52.text:
'Probably a trapped nerve,
or a carpal tunnel at worst'.

91.40.text:
I was never thinking
anything more serious.

96.47.text:
while I was waiting for them
they said to me,

100.97.text:
it could be Huntington's disease,
or it could be Wilson's disease'.

104.96.text:
And in the weirdest thing
that anyone's probably ever thought,

109.61.text:
because the other ones you die from,
and I wasn't ready to die.

117.56.text: This was eventually my diagnosis date.

121.25.text: It took a little while to get there,

122.96.text:
but it was actually a day that for me
was a day of decisiveness,

129.19.text:
It was the day where I knew
how to move forward

131.39.text: and how to proceed with things.

133.11.text:
It was also a day that I had
my family around me.

135.75.text:
We went on a fun family day out that day,
because we were all together,

139.17.text:
we just thought, 'We're here,
let's do something fun'.

143.34.text:
And it became the day that I knew
where my support network was,

146.29.text:
that they were around me,
they were there for good to help me.

149.19.text:
And every text I got,
I got more and more positive in return.

152.32.text:
One of my juniors at work
sent me a text saying,

155.13.text:
'Trust you to get
an old person's disease'.

157.47.text:
And I thought, 'Great,
that's the level we're going for'.

161.17.text: We were back to normal immediately.

165.91.text:
There's 127,000 people currently in the UK
living with Parkinson's disease,

170.68.text: I am just one of those people.

173.08.text:
But I have been given an opportunity
to tell my story countless times,

176.66.text:
and I think that's because
I put a slant on it

180.66.text: It's definitely easy for people to digest,

182.67.text:
but it's also made it easier for me
to come to terms with it.

186.70.text:
Because ultimately,
I was dealt this big, old,

191.61.text:
ugly package of Parkinson's and I thought,
'What am I going to do with it?

195.26.text:
I've got to find out what to do with it
to make my life good,

199.27.text:
and make my life strong,
and to make decisions for myself'.

204.37.text:
I couldn't change
what was happening to me.

209.61.text: I had a lack of dopamine in my system,

212.17.text:
and that is something
that is a massive deal.

214.64.text:
If anyone knows anything
about Parkinson's,

217.07.text: Parkinson's causes a lack of dopamine,

219.55.text:
a chemical which controls temperature,
mood, your movements,

224.18.text:
the way your brain communicates
with every single muscle in your body.

227.47.text:
You're fighting a battle
against your brain

229.60.text: and you're not going to win.

231.51.text: But I thought, 'I can repackage this.

234.09.text: I work in branding, I can repackage this

236.41.text:
and actually make it something
that works for me and that I enjoy'.

241.31.text: So I'm still dealing with the same thing,

243.72.text: but I'm dealing with it in a way

245.26.text:
that leads me to positivity
and happiness, ultimately.

249.32.text: And I'd love to share with you

251.21.text:
the ways that I've actually
found happiness

253.20.text: in something as big as Parkinson's.

256.02.text: Some is through what I'm wearing.

261.42.text:
So I'm going to share with you
my ten ways to find happiness

264.25.text: when it really doesn't want to be found.

266.48.text:
These are the ten ways that I've looked
to what I have as a situation

270.04.text: and actually made it my own,

271.50.text:
and made it something
that I'm happy and proud of.

281.05.text: Ultimately, if you go searching for it,

283.60.text:
you're not going to find
anything long-term.

286.34.text:
I've looked for it in the form
of men on white horses

290.39.text: carrying armour and things like that.

292.39.text:
I've looked for it in the bottom
of Häagen-Dazs tubs.

295.22.text:
I've looked for it in the bottom
of the scrolling page on ASOS.

301.46.text:
And ultimately, you find happiness
for a fleeting time with those things,

307.32.text:
and I know that's a massive,
massive cliché,

309.36.text:
probably everyone's told
you it a thousand times.

312.14.text:
But if you're happy in yourself
and who you are,

315.07.text: then you promote happiness to other people

317.71.text: and that comes back to you sevenfold.

319.86.text:
The people around you
will be happier as well.

327.40.text:
Never bring a prop on stage
when you have Parkinson's,

346.77.text:
It's okay to say
you are having a shit day.

349.90.text: It's okay to not be okay, you know.

352.63.text:
You can base on that old saying
which I love, which is,

355.51.text:
'You can cover a turd in glitter
but it will still be a turd, essentially'.

360.68.text:
If you experience the worst of days,
then you will experience the best of days.

365.03.text: You have to feel that unhappiness

366.61.text:
to feel the happiness
that you get from a good day

369.14.text:
and from good things
that are happening in your life.

371.87.text:
And ultimately, by saying to people,
'I'm having a terrible day'.

377.06.text:
and by actually being someone that has
to go out and talk about Parkinson's,

382.12.text:
if I'm selling it as something
that is amazing,

384.46.text:
and it's all about
tinsel tops and things like that.

386.91.text: It's not. It's actually incredibly hard.

390.02.text:
But by being honest with people,
they know how to treat me,

393.13.text:
they know what I expect from them,
what I do and don't want help with.

396.69.text: And it makes it easy for all of us.

398.35.text:
Because every time I tell someone
I have Parkinson's,

400.82.text: I know it breaks their heart a little bit.

402.82.text:
It may be the tenth time
I'm telling someone

404.89.text:
but it's the first time
they're hearing it.

421.38.text: with yourself, not with other people,

423.15.text:
because that does not lead
to happiness on anyone's time.

427.50.text:
Be impatient with yourself
and don't settle.

429.81.text:
I could have very easily
hidden in a corner,

432.87.text:
with slippers on, on a chair,
done nothing for the rest of my life,

436.01.text: and no one would have judged me for it

437.83.text: because it's a big thing to deal with.

440.39.text:
But I do more now
than I've ever done before,

442.63.text:
and that is because I feel
like I have nothing to lose.

445.85.text:
What's the worst that could happen?
I'll get Parkinson's? Done that, you know.

453.74.text:
So, because of that, I kind of go out
and do more than ever before.

457.67.text:
I would encourage
other people to do the same.

459.81.text:
Live as if it's the last opportunity
to do something.

464.12.text:
I say yes too much, and to be fair
I need to say no a little bit more,

469.60.text:
But it's definitely a great opportunity
to try new things,

472.31.text:
when you suddenly
get thrown into a situation

474.42.text:
where you're dealing
with something so new.

486.95.text:
Remember that everyone
is going through something as well.

490.28.text:
It might be something tiny to you,
but it might be something massive to them.

495.12.text:
And actually, by being kind
to other people

497.40.text:
and realizing that -- you know,
the guy that pushes past you on the train,

501.28.text:
he might have had
a really rubbish day at work;

504.06.text:
the woman who is letting
her child cry in the corner,

506.58.text: and you stood there tutting at them,

508.65.text:
someone in their family
may have just passed away.

511.08.text:
You don't know
what's happening in their lives.

513.68.text:
And actually, by being
more tolerant of others,

515.95.text: it makes you happier in yourself.

518.22.text:
I suddenly realized, as someone in London,
it's an incredibly fast-paced place.

523.95.text:
Everyone's rushing
to get somewhere and do something,

526.48.text: and pushing other people out of the way.

528.41.text:
And it's nice to take the time
to consider what other people are feeling.

532.63.text:
That tolerance comes back to you
like a boomerang,

534.98.text:
because if you're kind to other people,
people are ultimately kind to you.

538.64.text: It takes sometimes a while to get there,

540.56.text: and it might not be the same kind person,

542.51.text: but it comes back to you eventually.

552.49.text:
Wear flat shoes,
I cannot stress this enough.

556.66.text:
If you have unhappy feet,
you have an unhappy mind,

559.31.text: and that's all I can say about it.

560.93.text:
I've got a slight heel on today,
but we're talking like tiny,

567.73.text:
Wear trainers whenever you can
because it's just --

570.33.text:
when you're diagnosed
with something like Parkinson's,

572.85.text:
you can wear them to clubs
and get away with murder,

576.87.text:
But some people trot around town
all the time in heels,

579.45.text: and I feel sorry for them.

581.22.text:
I feel sorry they have
to wear heels all the time,

583.57.text: because no one is happy in heels.

586.82.text: If they're saying they are, they're lying.

595.57.text: I like to say this sentence to myself

597.61.text:
because I think I've been very, very lucky
in the people that I have around me,

602.33.text:
but I found my port in a storm
before the winds came.

606.20.text:
I knew who my people were
before I needed them.

609.18.text:
And that meant that
when I looked for them, they were there.

613.03.text:
And I knew that I was sorted,
and sturdy, and supported.

616.99.text:
Sometimes, if you think
people are going to be there,

620.40.text:
you're not 100% sure
until you need them whether they are,

623.20.text:
you may not have been there
for them in the past,

627.45.text:
And having a support network
when something bad's happening,

630.26.text: or when good stuff is happening,

634.14.text: It's great to stand on your own,

635.66.text:
but it's also really important
to have a team around you

638.30.text: that are there cheering you on.

647.58.text: I don't mean like die or anything,

649.31.text: we're not going to get that dark.

650.89.text: I mean, don't be a grown-up.

653.42.text: Run around, do what you can.

656.49.text:
Wearing trainers definitely
helps with that, I find.

660.98.text: People don't laugh at silly things enough.

663.29.text:
I've been laughing in my head
at the name Trump

668.42.text: I feel I'm the only one doing that,

670.09.text:
I'm hoping other people here
do that every time as well.

672.79.text: Great, that lady is nodding. Fantastic!

676.98.text:
It's kind of running on the grass
when you're not supposed to

681.13.text:
wearing tops like this
when you're supposed to be a grown-up.

684.90.text:
When suddenly you're dealt something
that's really massive,

687.70.text:
you realise that actually you can't be
ashamed of yourself anymore,

691.60.text:
you have to just get on
with being yourself and doing what you do.

697.88.text: But I think children have it right,

700.01.text:
they have it set in their minds
what they want to do,

702.49.text: they're just going to do it and have fun.

704.72.text:
As we grow up, that kind of gets
shaken out of us a little bit.

708.06.text:
This man's socks here
are filling me with great joy,

710.49.text: because he's the man that likes colour.

713.23.text:
We should wear more colour,
and be happy, and be children at heart.

726.18.text:
but really appreciate
the small stuff that you can do.

730.69.text:
I would say I never really appreciated
steady hands, a firm handshake,

738.83.text:
until those things became
more difficult for me.

741.95.text:
So, don't get hung up
on the day-to-day little things

746.00.text:
but appreciate the things
that you take for granted.

749.76.text:
I hug someone now and it feels
like I'm about to attack them

752.80.text:
because it's all kind of --
or I'm frisking them or something.

757.24.text:
It's great to know that you can go
into a room and feel confident,

761.92.text:
and having something like Parkinson's
stops that from happening.

765.18.text:
But I now appreciate
the things that I can do

767.77.text: so much more than I ever could before.

769.64.text:
So the tiny things that I'm left with,
that I know I can still do,

772.75.text:
being able to stand up
in front of a room of people,

775.17.text:
fills me with so much joy and happiness
because I can still do it.

778.50.text:
And screw it, I'm going to it
for as long as I can!

786.68.text: Find something that is your cause,

788.75.text: of what you want to stand up for in life,

792.51.text:
Mine is slightly narcissistic,
because it's Parkinson's.

797.09.text:
I should have other causes
that I look up to as well.

800.15.text:
But actually, before I was diagnosed,
I didn't really fight for anything.

804.12.text:
Now I fight for my own life,
my own existence,

806.52.text: and what I want to do in my life.

809.81.text:
I'm a kind of mouthpiece
for those people as well.

814.16.text:
there are other causes out there
that I could lend myself to,

817.02.text: and I could do more for them.

819.55.text: Maybe not be such a narcissist.

822.46.text:
that I cared about
that passionately before.

824.79.text:
I never did charity work,
I never did anything like that.

829.21.text:
that we have an opportunity to do
those things to help people.

832.39.text:
We have a mouth, we have arms,
we can do things to help people.

849.10.text: I stand in front of you as someone

850.72.text:
who physically
looks nervous, looks scared.

854.52.text:
Perhaps it might seem
a little bit frightening

856.73.text:
if you're in London
and you see someone shaking,

858.97.text: in the times we're in at the moment,

860.73.text:
everyone is aware
of what everyone else is doing

863.09.text: and keeping an eye on people.

865.55.text:
But if you look into my eyes
and you hear me speak,

869.14.text: you know who I am, you see me as a person.

871.41.text:
And I have the opportunity,
I can tell my story,

874.76.text:
But a lot of people don't have
that opportunity.

878.21.text:
It's knowing that the body is just a shell
for the good stuff that's inside.

883.03.text:
The brain and heart is where
the important stuff happens,

887.59.text:
And it's looking into people's eyes
when you talk to them,

890.60.text: it's being more tolerant to people

892.39.text:
and knowing that
we're all the same, ultimately.

896.70.text:
But I have been left
with a fantastic Parkinson's situation

902.30.text:
out of my slightly rubbish package
that I was given at the beginning.

907.73.text: That is not a different package,

909.75.text: that is what I was given to start with.

914.39.text:
I haven't changed that in any way,
there's no way I can change that,

917.62.text: my chemical make-up is still the same.

920.13.text:
But the way that I see it
is completely different.

922.89.text:
The way I feel about Parkinson's
is completely different.

925.56.text:
The way that I feel about the world
is completely different.

928.58.text:
I would just implore you
to look at your own situation,

931.15.text:
see what you can do
to make yourself happy,

933.15.text:
because being happy
is an incredible thing.

935.34.text: And ultimately, it's in our hands.
